ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a much richer understanding of the seven thinkers we read, and I now feel like I could articulate the key points of any of their philosophies.

I learned a lot about tons of philosophers and their various theories on ethics, politics, and economics and how each tie into each other. I also learned a lot about comparing philosophy theories between different people from all different time periods

I learned about the intellectual developments of the last several centuries relating to ethics, economics, and politics. We went in depth in 6 interdisciplinary thinkers and compared and contrasted them extensively.
Great insight on some of the classic philosophers of politics and ethics. Very detailed explanations by professor on very hard to read writings helped immensely.
Interpretation of texts by great thinkers, ability to trace and see connections through the lens of political theorists
Classics of ethics, politics & economics
I learned the fundamentals of ethical, political, and economic interdisciplinary thought.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: discussions go deeply into the text while keeping the reading load manageable. 
Weaknesses: it would be nice to add more diversity to the reading list and to include more modern thinkers
I think that the course was very well organized and laid out to cover all core philosophers and their most important theories. I enjoyed the discussions that stemmed in class

Strengths: Prof. Kapustin is unbelievably knowledgable and helpful in understanding these philosophers better, the sessions are a great balance of discussion and instruction; Weaknesses: the weekly reading is a bit overwhelming (I was very rarely able to finish all of it), but that won't stop you from being able to follow along during sessions

Kapustin's lectures are awesome, I love hearing him speak and he does a wonderful job explaining complex topics. The class feels more like a lecture, which is not a bad things. I think focusing on 6 thinkers was great because we time to dive into each. However, we did always end up behind every week.

Professor Kapustin is a great teacher. He is obviously very knowledgeable regarding the topics but he truly went out of his way to explain quite difficult texts to us. He is the course's greatest asset. 
The texts are difficult and intimidating but trust that Kapustin's seminar explanations will be incredibly helpful and ease anxieties.

Strengths: Kapustin is a wonderful lecturer, organization of the assignments was very clear, readings were well chosen and all spoke to big questions through different lenses
Weaknesses: More active student engagement (not enough people spoke up or did the readings), more seminar-style discussion than lecture
Strengths are 100% Boris. no real weaknesses

The course is excellent, mostly because of Professor Kapustin who is one of the most incredible instructors at Yale. You would do yourself a great service to take a class with him for his knowledge and kindness as a professor.

Prof Kapustin is a wonderful man and a great teacher/lecturer. However, the course canon jumps a considerable stretch of time from Bentham to Schumpeter etc. Further, it only included white men no women, or people of color were covered. I understand that this is a classics course, but surely we could have included other perspectives.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! Most likely you'll only be taking this class if you're an EP&E major, in which case you have to, but I still think you can get a lot out of it. It's a great way to build off of Intro Political Philosophy courses.
Absolutely. Anyone interested in this subject matter should take it.
Yes I enjoyed learning about new theories I had previously been unaware of
Yes. This is the only Yale philosophy class that I've ever felt has been worth my time. If you are interested in human nature or political infrastructure, this is a great class to take.
Well if you're an EP&E major you have no choice, but it's a great class and very interesting content. I see why it is a requirement!
If you're talking this you likely have to for EPE. I wouldn't recommend this specific course as the material is dense and niche but I for sure recommend Kapustin.
yes! to anyone who cares about philosophy

I would absolutely recommend it. If you think it looks interesting, the EP&E major might be for you. If you just want to take a class with Prof. Kapustin but are not an EP&E major, I'd recommend one of his other ones just because the content might be a little more generally appealing.
Yes, it's required!
